Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Electron Microprobe (EMP) for analysis of inorganic elemental concentrations in solid-state materials: Expanding science research and teaching in Iowa.
Award.AbstractNarration:
1126728
Ukstins-Peate

This Major Research Instrumentation grant supports acquisition of a state-of-the-art electron microprobe (EMP) equipped with five wavelength dispersive spectrometers (WDS), an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS), and cathodoluminescence spectrometer. The EMP will support a range of research and research training across multiple departments on campus with broad themes including: 1) Earth Processes; 2) Sustainability & Climate Change; 3) Pollution Prevention & Remediation; 4) Planetary Geology & Meteorite Impacts; 5) Geoarchaeology; and 6) Public Health, all with needs for microspatially resolved quantitative chemical analysis of solid materials. Example research applications include innovative and promising studies of the conditions of magmagenesis as recorded in arc volcanics and tectonic investigations relying on study of metamorphic rock suites through use of EMP geothermbarometric techniques as well as studies of bolide impact processes, paleoclimate investigations of relict lake deposits, and studies of nanoparticle aggregates and the role of microbes in the chemical cycling of heavy metals. The PIs plan to engage underrepresented students in research experiences using the EMP through an extant Alliance for Graduate Education and Professoriate (AGEP) and the Ethnic Inclusion Program in Iowa Engineering institutional wide programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF MRI funded Electron Microprobe Laboratory at the University of Iowa provides state-of-the-art in situ major and trace element analyses of solid state materials at the parts per million to parts per billion level. In the first year of data collection, the lab supported research of >45 faculty, graduate students, and undergraduates at the University of Iowa, plus researchers from the midwestern US and faculty from international institutions who also use the facility. Faculty have thus far generated more than $1,000,000 in research grants which rely on the lab for data collection, and 15 graduate students have used the lab to conduct their thesis research. Outreach activities include university class laboratory exercises, analytical classes focused on EPMA, lab tours for visiting students and perspective students.

The following publications are a selection of research that utilized data from the EPMA laboratory:

  • D Peate, D Perna, A Moritz, P Schumacher, M Riishuus, D Burns, I Ukstins Peate (2015). Complexities of melt generation and storage in an off-rift setting on the Snaefellsnes Peninsula of Iceland revealed through detailed study of the Berserkjahraun volcano field. North Central GSA.
  • S Saltzman, I Ukstins Peate (2015). Disentangling high frequency climate oscillations in a volcanic setting: Laguna Lejia Chile. North Central GSA.
  • S Saltzman, I Ukstins Peate. S Giralt, DW Peate, B van Alderwerelt (2016). Disentangling high frequency climate oscillations in a volcanic setting: Laguna Lejia, Chile. AGU.
  • K Rathbun, I Ukstins Peate (2015). Investigation of a possible link between external morphology and internal texture in impact melt ejecta from Monturaqui Crater, Chile. North Central GSA.
  • B van Alderwerelt, I Ukstins Peate, F Ramos, S Saltzman, D Burns (2015). Mafic volcanism and the deep crust in the Central Andes: In situ geochemistry and isotopic composition of young, small-­volume mafic eruptions. AGU.
  • B van Alderwerelt, I Ukstins Peate, D Burns, F Ramos (2015). Magmatic evolution of young, small volume mafic eruptive centers in the Chilean Altiplano utilizing in situ geochemical and isotopic data. IUGG IAVCEI.
  • D Peate, D Burney, D Perna, A Moritz, P Sgcumacher, M Riishuus, D Burns, I Ukstins Peate (2015). Reconstructing the plumbing system beneath young monogenetic mafic eruptions in an off-rift setting on the Snaefellsness Peninsula of Iceland. IUGG IAVCEI.
  • I Ukstins Peate, S Shangguan, W Tian (2015). Volcanic stratigraphy and near-vent deposits of the Tarim flood basalts, NW China. IUGG IAVCEI.
